question: It is true that process scheduling is responsible for managing the execution of multiple processes in a computer.
It is false that the CPU can execute multiple processes at the same time in a single-core system.
It is true that a job queue contains all processes that are ready to be executed.
It is false that a ready queue contains processes that are currently running on the CPU.
It is true that a waiting queue holds processes that are waiting for I/O operations to complete.
It is false that the long-term scheduler runs frequently to select the next process for execution.
It is true that the short-term scheduler runs frequently to select which process gets CPU time.
It is false that the medium-term scheduler is responsible for swapping processes in and out of memory.
It is true that context switching allows the CPU to switch from one process to another.
It is false that context switching does not require saving the state of a process before switching.
It is true that the job queue includes all processes in the system, including those that are completed.
It is false that a ready queue contains processes that are waiting for I/O operations to complete.
It is true that the short-term scheduler decides which process gets CPU time next.
It is false that the long-term scheduler runs more frequently than the short-term scheduler.
It is true that a medium-term scheduler is responsible for swapping processes in and out of memory.
It is false that process scheduling is unnecessary in modern operating systems.
It is true that a CPU scheduler is also known as a short-term scheduler.
It is false that the ready queue contains only one process at a time.
It is true that context switching can cause a slight delay in process execution.
It is false that the medium-term scheduler decides which process gets CPU time.
It is true that scheduling queues help manage processes waiting to be executed.
It is false that the short-term scheduler selects processes from the job queue.
It is true that a context switch involves saving and loading process states.
It is false that a process can move from the waiting queue directly to the running state.
It is true that job scheduling occurs less frequently than CPU scheduling.
It is false that every process in a system is always in a ready queue.
It is true that context switching is necessary for multitasking in operating systems.
It is false that scheduling queues are only used for long-term scheduling.
It is true that process scheduling is essential for efficient CPU utilization.
It is false that a process in the waiting queue does not require CPU time.
